issue.title: [BUG] long fh does not work for specific forecasting pipeline

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
posted by @anthonygiorgio97 in #2452
(added some missing imports)
---

Another strange behaviour is that if `fh=[1,2]` the code below works, but if `fh=[1,2,3]` or `[1,2,3,4],...` or longer, I have error:

```python
from sktime.forecasting.compose import make_reduction, ForecastingPipeline, TransformedTargetForecaster
from sktime.forecasting.model_selection import ExpandingWindowSplitter, temporal_train_test_split, ForecastingGridSearchCV
from sktime.forecasting.fbprophet import Prophet
from sktime.transformations.series.adapt import TabularToSeriesAdaptor
from sktime.transformations.series.boxcox import LogTransformer
from sktime.transformations.series.compose import OptionalPassthrough
from sktime.transformations.series.difference import Differencer

from sklearn.preprocessing import StandardScaler
from sklearn.svm import SVR
from sktime.datasets import load_longley

y, X = load_longley()

#split train/test both y and X
fh = [1,2,3]
train_model, test_model = temporal_train_test_split(y, fh = fh)
X_train = X[X.index.isin(train_model.index)]
X_test = X[X.index.isin(test_model.index)]

#pipeline
pipe = TransformedTargetForecaster(steps = [
            ("log", OptionalPassthrough(LogTransformer())),
            ("differencer", Differencer(drop_na = True)),
            ("scaler", TabularToSeriesAdaptor(StandardScaler())),
            ("myforecasterpipe", ForecastingPipeline(steps = [
                ("logX", OptionalPassthrough(LogTransformer())),
                ("differencerX", Differencer(drop_na = True)),
                ("scalerX", TabularToSeriesAdaptor(StandardScaler())),
                ("myforecaster", make_reduction(SVR()))
        ]))  
])

#cv setup
N_cv_fold = 1
step_cv = 1
cv = ExpandingWindowSplitter(initial_window = len(train_model) - (N_cv_fold - 1) * step_cv - len(fh),
                            start_with_window = True,
                            step_length = step_cv,
                            fh = fh)

param_grid = [{"log__passthrough": [False],
               "myforecasterpipe__logX__passthrough": [False],
               "myforecasterpipe__myforecaster__window_length": [2,3],
               "myforecasterpipe__myforecaster__estimator__C": [10,100]
              },
              {"log__passthrough": [True],
               "myforecasterpipe__logX__passthrough": [True],
               "myforecasterpipe__myforecaster__window_length": [2,3],
               "myforecasterpipe__myforecaster__estimator__C": [10,100]
              }
             ]

#grid search
gscv = ForecastingGridSearchCV(
            forecaster = pipe,
            cv=cv,
            param_grid=param_grid,
            verbose = 1
        )

#fit
gscv.fit(train_model, X = X_train)
```

Error:

`ValueError: could not broadcast input array from shape (5,2) into shape (1,5,3)`

I think the problem regards the `inverse_transform` of `Differencer` on exogenous variable used for validation, when we have to do prediction in validation set. But I don't understand why for forecasting horizon `[1,2]` it works.

_Originally posted by @anthonygiorgio97 in https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/2452#issuecomment-1100855032_

body:
Could you perhaps be a bit more explicit what you mean by "not treating as forecaster until the very last step"?

This "relaxing of typing" PR could be related - is it?
https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/pull/2842

Yes I would agree the "relaxing of typing" PR is relevant, thank you for linking it. 

And yes - would be happy to be more explicit!  I am still in the process of tracing all the code relevant to this, so this is probably a less than perfect understanding, but from what I could tell: 
- in the example which came up in issue 2807 `ForecastingGridSearch` we end up pre-trimming all `X` in a `fh` dependent manner via `_split` before passing it to `TransformedTargetForecaster`
- but in reality, if we are working with something like `TransformedTargetForecaster` I think it doesn't really makes sense to trim the `X` until right before the forecasting step? (Usually it isn't an issue, but it will come up with transformers that change the size of `X` like we saw) 
- so the thought was, is there a way we can delay some of these pre-processing steps that are forecaster-specific until the step in `TransformedTargetForecaster` that is right before the actual forecasting part? 

I am not actually sure that the second bullet point above actually holds.  Is this a valid point, or are their actual cases where we would need to trim the `X` in this manner for transformers as well? I think my understanding on this might be less than perfect!

> so the thought was, is there a way we can delay some of these pre-processing steps that are forecaster-specific until the step in TransformedTargetForecaster that is right before the actual forecasting part?

Isn't that what #2842 was trying to achieve, by setting pipeline tags to the "relaxed" one where no trimming takes place, instead of copying that one from the forecaster?

> but in reality, if we are working with something like `TransformedTargetForecaster` I think it doesn't really makes sense to trim the `X` until right before the forecasting step

I think your understanding is correct, but also I thought `TransformedTargetForecaster` does not trim `X`?

>> but in reality, if we are working with something like TransformedTargetForecaster I think it doesn't really makes sense to trim the X until right before the forecasting step
>
> I think your understanding is correct, but also I thought TransformedTargetForecaster does not trim X?

I think I agree - however I was referring to the trimming that goes on in `ForecastingGridSearchCV` (in the function `_split` it runs in `fit`). So my point was - we end up pre-trimming for all forecasters when we use `ForecastingGridSearchCV` (I think) but that doesn't really make sense for all forecasters (eg `TransforemdTargetForecaster`)

> I think I agree - however I was referring to the trimming that goes on in `ForecastingGridSearchCV`

I see - good catch!

So, I assume, we should not pre-trim there. Could anything bad happen if we don't, e.g., leakage?
If not, we should remove the trimming. What do you think?

Where are we currently trimming?
I will make a PR attempting to fix this!  Lets see if that solves it or not!
@miraep8, quick question: does this PR exist already? Totally fine if left for later, just checking.

issue.title: [BUG] Delay trimming in ForecastingGridSearchCV until after transforming

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.title: [BUG] Delay trimming in ForecastingGridSearchCV until after transforming

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

body: PR has been added.  I think this PR generally seems to solve the problem, though there could be remaining issues with trimming issues in TransformedTargetForecaster.   Ideally instead of just returning the whole range of preceding data (as my solution does) we would be able to just add a buffer which depends on the amount trimmed by the pipeline, but as that solution is slightly more involved my solution just takes the nave approach of returning the entire window.

Hm, interesting thought.

I have a generic "memory" PR for transformers here:
https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/pull/3307
which is a bit related.

How would the generic buffer work? The problem I see is that the buffer could depend on the parameters of the estimator. Simple example: `Lag`, where the buffer size would be the maximum lag.

I guess a way one could do it is - all transformers have a new attribute called `buffer`.  The default for all transformers is for this required buffer to be zero, however the private method which determines the buffer size could be overwritten by the children classes and can be set to be some arbitrary function of the parameters.  

The (linear) pipeline's `buffer` would be the sum on constituent transformer's buffers.
hm, yes, that could work. Although feels a bit overengineered. What would be example cases where we would override the buffer? Could there not be just a default buffer?

issue.title: [BUG] `model_evaluation.evaluate` fails for `statsmodels` forecasters with exogenous features

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
**Describe the bug**

model_evaluation.evaluate creates X_test containing both train and test samples.  For statsmodels models with exogenous features X_test length must equal the forecast horizon and therefore this currently throws the error:

`ValueError: Provided exogenous values are not of the appropriate shape.`

This bug occurs for UnobservedComponents and SARIMAX.

The root cause of the bug is in the `_split` function:
https://github.com/sktime/sktime/blob/a5f824a5fff1c3fc1babd3f34b94c5055ec040b0/sktime/forecasting/model_evaluation/_functions.py#L60

This could be modified to 'X.iloc[test].sort_index()' for statsmodels models with exogenous features or alternatively by filtering X here:
https://github.com/sktime/sktime/blob/a5f824a5fff1c3fc1babd3f34b94c5055ec040b0/sktime/forecasting/base/adapters/_statsmodels.py#L104

**To Reproduce**

```python
from sktime.datasets import load_longley
from sktime.forecasting.structural import UnobservedComponents
from sktime.forecasting.model_evaluation import evaluate
from sktime.forecasting.model_selection import SlidingWindowSplitter

y, X = load_longley()

forecaster = UnobservedComponents(level='local linear trend')

cv = SlidingWindowSplitter(fh=[1,2,3],
                           window_length = 4,
                           step_length = 1)

results = evaluate(
        forecaster=forecaster, y=y, X = X,
        cv=cv, strategy='refit', return_data=True,
        error_score = 'raise'
        )
```

**Versions**

System:
python: 3.8.12 (default, Nov 20 2022, 10:50:06)  [Clang 14.0.0 (clang-1400.0.29.202)]
machine: macOS-13.0.1-arm64-arm-64bit

Python dependencies:
          pip: 21.2
   setuptools: 63.1.0
      sklearn: 1.1.3
       sktime: 0.14.0
  statsmodels: 0.13.5
        numpy: 1.22.0
        scipy: 1.9.3
       pandas: 1.4.1
   matplotlib: 3.6.2
       joblib: 1.2.0
        numba: 0.56.4
     pmdarima: None
      tsfresh: None

issue.title: [BUG] fix `statsmodels` estimators when exogenous `X` is passed with more indices than `fh`

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
#### Reference Issues/PRs

Fixes [#3830](https://github.com/sktime/sktime/issues/3830)

#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.

Statsmodels with exogenous features would raise an exception in `predict` if `X` contained more indices than the range of `fh`.
This was due to all indices being passed through to `statsmodels` `predict`.  The fix ensures that only the expected `X` indices from the test set are passed to `statsmodels` `predict`.

Fixes #3830 as this was also the root cause of the exception raised when using `evaluate` with `statsmodels` based estimators.

#### Does your contribution introduce a new dependency? If yes, which one?

No

#### What should a reviewer concentrate their feedback on?

#### Any other comments?

#### PR checklist
<!--
Please go through the checklist below. Please feel free to remove points if they are not applicable.
-->

##### For all contributions
- [x] I've added myself to the [list of contributors](https://github.com/sktime/sktime/blob/main/.all-contributorsrc).
- [ ] Optionally, I've updated sktime's [CODEOWNERS](https://github.com/sktime/sktime/blob/main/CODEOWNERS) to receive notifications about future changes to these files.
- [x] I've added unit tests and made sure they pass locally.
- [x] The PR title starts with either [ENH], [MNT], [DOC], or [BUG] indicating whether the PR topic is related to enhancement, maintenance, documentation, or bug.

##### For new estimators
- [ ] I've added the estimator to the online documentation.
- [ ] I've updated the existing example notebooks or provided a new one to showcase how my estimator works.
